author: Special Correspondent
text:
Chief Minister Jayalalithaa inaugurated, through video conferencing, the underground drainage facility in Pudukottai on Saturday. Work on providing the facility was taken up by the Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Drainage Board at an estimate of Rs.48.16 crore. The TWAD Board set up sewage pipes to a cumulative length of 151.8 km across 37 wards in the municipal town. It included 5,455 manholes.

Machinery had been set up at an expenditure of Rs.7.21 crore for treating the sewage at Maruppini Pulpannai near here. The facility would benefit residents of 20,000 domestic units which had been linked with the underground drainage system. The daily treatment capacity is 10.62 million litres, according to Jeeva. Subramanian, Municipal Commissioner.

The treated water will be discharged into the grass farm of the municipality. “Pudukottai municipality will optimally utilise the treated water,” says official source. The municipality has drawn up a special plan for providing the facility in five wards which were merged with the municipality about four years ago.

R. Rajasekar, Municipal Chairman, said that the underground drainage facility has evoked good response from the residents. As many as 8,000 tax-payers -- all under ‘domestic’ units – had remitted the deposit of Rs.5,000 each, indicating their preparedness to utilise the scheme. The deposit for the commercial units was Rs.8,000, he added.
title: Underground drainage facility inaugurated
